‘⁶ The calcination of tartar of red and white wine is thus made. Wash hard tartar often in water, and place it to be calcined in a reverberatory furnace, with little‘fire at first 3 augment it afterwards until it grows white inside. Then cast it into hot water in a clean vessel, and dissolve it with a clean spatula, and when it has become dissolved, allow it to cool. Afterwards pass it through a filter‚ then bear it upon the fire and inspissate that which is strained, and after- wards grind it and put it into an uncovered pot to caleine, until the pot is red hot, for one hour, perhaps; afterwards extract and grind and dissolve it in hot water and expose it to cool3 afterwards filter and evaporate, again calcine it as before another hour3 dis- solve, evaporate, and calcine it: when it runs upon a plate or the furnace without fume it is then proper for melting crystal.”
